reports.title: Viral Classroom Video Claiming ‘Islamic Indoctrination’ found to be Fake
reports.claim: A video is circulating online with the allegation that “young white children are being indoctrinated into Islam” and shown “raising their hands and chanting ‘Allahu Akbar’ in a classroom.”
reports.content:
Viral Classroom Video Claiming ‘Islamic Indoctrination’ found to be Fake
Fact Check en
November 19, 2025
November 19, 2025
Aayushi Rana
A video is circulating online with the allegation that “young white children are being indoctrinated into Islam” and shown “raising their hands and chanting ‘Allahu Akbar’ in a classroom.”
The video looks like it was filmed in an elementary or middle school classroom, with a date and time stamp like CCTV footage. It shows 12 children in school uniforms kneeling and repeating “Allahu Akbar” after a female teacher who appears to be wearing a hijab.
Link
Fact Check
Upon investigation, we found the claim and the video to be fake. A closer examination reveals two clear signs of digital manipulation:
1. The teacher appears to rise from her knees and sit down on a chair that is not visible at the start of the clip, nor is it seen being moved into the frame.
2. The child on the far left in the front row has a hair tie that abruptly changes size from large to normal within five seconds. Additionally, no media outlet has reported on such an incident occurring in any British school.
Conclusion
The viral video claiming that children in a British classroom were being “indoctrinated into Islam” is digitally altered. There is no evidence linking the footage to any school, and the visual inconsistencies confirm it is a manipulated clip.
DFRAC Analysis: Fake

reports.title: Allahabad High Court video falsely shared as a Supreme Court protest against vote theft
reports.claim: In a viral video on social media, lawyers can be seen walking on foot. Users are sharing this video claiming that it shows lawyers marching in the Supreme Court against vote theft. The text on the video reads, “The election will be cancelled Supreme Court. Against the vote thief.”While sharing this video, a user namedAdv. Nazneen Akhtarwrote, “A good step… friends what do you say should the election be cancelled?#vote_thief_leave_power”
reports.content:
Allahabad High Court video falsely shared as a Supreme Court protest against vote theft
Fact Check en
Misleading-en
November 18, 2025
November 18, 2025
Abhinav Singh
In a viral video on social media, lawyers can be seen walking on foot. Users are sharing this video claiming that it shows lawyers marching in the Supreme Court against vote theft. The text on the video reads, “The election will be cancelled Supreme Court. Against the vote thief.”
While sharing this video, a user named
Adv. Nazneen Akhtar
wrote, “A good step… friends what do you say should the election be cancelled?
#vote_thief_leave_power”
Link
Apart from this, the video is being shared by many other users with the same caption, which can be seen
here
and
here
.
Fact Check:
The DFRAC team found in the investigation that the viral video is not from the Supreme Court. This video is from October during the Allahabad High Court Bar Association election, where lawyers were appealing for votes. On reverse searching the key frames of the video, we found that this video was shared by Allahabad High Court lawyer Aditya Singh Hunter on his Instagram account on 19 October 2025.
Link
For more information about the video, our team contacted lawyer Aditya Singh Hunter. He told us that this video is from the time of the Allahabad High Court Bar Association election, when lawyers were appealing for votes. We found that several other videos related to the Bar Association election have also been posted on Aditya Singh’s
Instagram
account.
Conclusion:
The DFRAC fact check makes it clear that the video shared on social media is not of lawyers marching in the Supreme Court against vote theft. This video is of lawyers appealing for votes during the Bar Association election at the Allahabad High Court. Therefore, the users’ claim is misleading.

reports.title: Did Indian and Pakistani cricket players start brawls during a match in Sharjah?
reports.claim: Several social media users claim that a fight erupted during an India-Pakistan cricket match in Sharjah, UAE. The claim is also supported by a video that features Indian and Pakistani players fighting during the match.
reports.content:
Did Indian and Pakistani cricket players start brawls during a match in Sharjah?
Fact Check en
November 18, 2025
November 18, 2025
Abhinav Singh
Several social media users claim that a fight erupted during an India-Pakistan cricket match in Sharjah, UAE. The claim is also supported by a video that features Indian and Pakistani players fighting during the match.
A user on X, Vijayma70555375, posted this video with a caption on it that says, “Fight between Pakistani & Indian players in Sharjah”.
Link
Fact-Check
The DFRAC team analysed the video and the associated claim, determining that it is fake. The last cricket match between India and Pakistan took place during the Asia Cup final on September 28, 2025. Since then, no official cricket match has occurred between the two teams. Additionally, the claim that a fight broke out during a match in Sharjah is also fake. The last game held at Sharjah Cricket Stadium was on September 5, 2025, between Pakistan and the UAE as part of the T20I series.
Link
To verify the video’s authenticity, we took a screenshot and conducted a reverse image search. This led us to a TikTok user known for posting AI-generated videos, who first shared this fight video. The username of this account is jhatka_ai, and its bio indicates that it is specifically dedicated to posting AI-related content.
Link
Another TikTok video was posted by this user, depicting a fight between India and Pakistan during a cricket match. It was also created using AI.
Link
Conclusion
Therefore, both the video and the associated claim are fake. No recent match has occurred between India and Pakistan in Sharjah, and the video is generated by AI.
